esty solicited to attend the first day OF their mex

of the opposition, and particularly those who are

but vague dislike and indefinite objection.

Their now remains no chance OF defrautng the peo-
pie OF New York out of their votes by another bar
gain and SALE" This concession of weakness is no
less unequivocal than true. The flourish about

because the people would have the same influence
and security in an election by general ticket that
they have in one by districts The only difference
rs, that hv general ticket the majority of sufragcs

yet jackson get nearly half of the votes thereby

IN the Union to that Of one of the smallest If til,
Adams men were not confident of having decided
majority IN New York; why should they wish


general ticket And if the Jacksonites were nc

lection of the proposed alteration The answer
are plain. The friends Of the Administration ha
rather have the whole vote of New York than


part--and the advocates of jackson had rather hay
a part than none II is true that such propositio
has been made and rejected, but it was made. u
believe, preinaturely-the present not being II
proper session. for that purpose. Legslatu,
pfaewly elected members will meet during the a

An Opposition paper says 1t must be We y
gratifying to the friends of General Jackson, to pei
ceiye the firm and decisive manner in which good
old Virginia gives her support to him." In order
that the editor OF this paper may know little more
Of the manner in which Virginia supports his cand-
date, we will inform him that the FIRST step has been
taken towards the assembling of Convention in
that State, for the purpose of showing the citizens
Of the Union, that the Of the people will only
be expressed in an Administration ticket. There is
a powerful and growing sentiment ia Virginia, ia
vorabie to the reelection of Mr.. Adams whose po-
Icy has given general satisfaction, Notwithstanding
the clamor of those who speak through the columns
of the Richmond Enquirer. All the dscordances
which have existed in the public opinion of Virginia,
are fast settling down into an harmonious con-
victon that it would be folly to change President
and Administration whose course is we'll known and
approved, for one whose doubtful and conflicting
opinions, Judging from the conduct of his friends,
have left all parties in perpeyity to his princ-
plies and feelings, and whose morals and intelligence


nave come out of the fire to which they have been
necessarily subjected, without any increase Of pu-
rity or brightness.


We can tell the author of the paragraph with


which we commenced this article, on the authority
| OF a Jacksonlan who has just visited the counties oi


Frederick, Hardy and Hampshire, in Virginia that


he had very great difficulty to find any one to adyo-


cate the claims Of the General, so perfectly had


public opinion in those counties settled down in fa-
vor of the present Administration. To doubt that


what we have stated in this paragraph will be VIC.
lently denied and that shall be honored with 6
few coarse epthets for giving circulation TO the
facts would betray great ignorance of those
against whom we have to contend The han


gers-on at the Offices Of the jackson papers, are
+ as numerous and as public as the loterers who


lounge about Westminster Hall with straws in theil
hats, signltying that they are TO be purchased b,


such as have need of persons to according tc


their lesson. But the truth of our statements can
not be overthrow by such testimony. There il
not well informed 4 impartial Virglnian, who will
not sustain us. We will not pretend to give de
clded opinion as to the result Of the electoral vot
J, in Virginia, because We have not sufficient mate
+ rials for the formation of such: hut it require


nothing more than the ordinary use Of our faculties


to understand the direction to which the public sen
ment is tending and to conclude that this tendcn
. cy premises that result which we hope and believ
I twill produce.

have been sharreuesl By causes which do not meet

MS incendiarlcs in the strife for supremacy, are al

CONVENTION in Vl6JiNlA.


n, r,,i,e and 10 organize On opposition TO re Fec

II 10 knswn that the constitution of the United
States directs the appointment ol President once
in fur wears for which purpose Electors are to o.
.nnointed nv each state, in such manner az the lie
pislature thereof may direct. 1t also known that
fhe Legislature of Virginia has. by existing law d.
reried these electors to be chosen by the feople o
The State. in the form Of a General llcket To pe
eonpnscd of an elector resident IN each electoral
district within the State. And whereas it has been
+he practce of the members Of our General Assem-
by without express or implied, authority from
their constituents to that end, mt only to form an
Electoral Ticket, but to dictate its acceptance by
inposny combinations for its support at kirhmnnu'
and in every county in the state. Aud whereas ths
nr,ctice Of unauthorized dctation and the exercise
Of an influence conded BY the People for other pur-
n,ses il calculated to deprive the People of their CON
stitutional right oeect president, without intrigue
or corrption And especially asl is believed that
many members Of our present General assembly
who are friendly to the election OF Andrew Jackson
will not. in that respect, promote the wishes ol tne
constituents For the purpose OF countervaliihg
these abuses. and in lieu thereof to afford the voers
of Virginia. for the first time, an opportunity TO form
their ovn Ticket. and thus rraciicaNyio vote i'r
the President Of their choice, it is designed to invite
the voters of each county in the State opposed 10
the election of Andrew jackson, to attend at their
respectiye Court Houses, on the first day OF the
Court to be held for November next for the pur-
pose of appointing Delegates to form Convention
to convene in the City Of Richmond OIL the hlst
Tuesday in January next, whose duty IT shall be 10
nrenare an Electoral Ticket cnnsonant with the wish
es Of those whom they represent to be denonnated
the Peoples Tickets and to make every arrange
,nen necessary to give effect to the object OF their
meeting. Believing that better .lan than the
one above indicated, cannot be devised as the Con
stituton now is, to secure to the People full and
free expression of their opinions IN the choice OF
Presidents the voters in the county of hinE George
who are opposed to the election of Andrew Jackson.
to the Presidency. are most respectfully and earn
esty solicited to attend the first day OF their mex
November Court, at the Court House, for the pur
pose of appointing suitable Delegates to the aore
said Convention.

We are, it is well known ourselves, opposed to
the election OF Gen. jackson but we would bite off
our tongue before we would speak of the victor at
New Orleans N the vituperative terms which some
of the opposition, and particularly those who are
now his most outrageous supporters, have, within
four years past, permitted themselves to use to-
wards him. History affords no example of a coali-
ton of nlonstrouS characfer-of an nqnoIoo,on.
ton IF materials so Heterogeneous as that which
now displays its gorgon standard of opposition to an
Administration to the government against which no.
thing can truly be alleged (Which might not have
been alleged against any preceding Administration
but vague dislike and indefinite objection.

1t never has been seriously donhted that "A large
majority Of the People of New York arc in favor of
fhe National Administration, hut the first open
acknowledgement of this fact by the CoMBIN ALTON, we
find in the Philadelphia Sentinel of Tuesday-a pa-
per which seems to be the popular oracle OF the
P snnsylvania Jacksontes. The Editor exults at
fae rejection of proposition, made some days ago
in the New York senate. to change the mode Of ell
ecton from the DIsTRIcr to a GENERAL TICKET
System and adds g The HOPE of procuring an.
alteration in this law, upon which the friends of
ADAMS have been resting, is thus dissipated, and
Their now remains no chance OF defrautng the peo-
pie OF New York out of their votes by another bar
gain and SALE" This concession of weakness is no
less unequivocal than true. The flourish about
"BARGAIN AND SALE is at once vile and stupid !;
because the people would have the same influence
and security in an election by general ticket that
they have in one by districts The only difference
rs, that hv general ticket the majority of sufragcs
carry the whole thirysix votes of the State for the
favorte candid ,te, whereas by the District system
three-tourths Of the people may be for Adams, and
yet jackson get nearly half of the votes thereby
reducing the influence of the most powerful State
IN the Union to that Of one of the smallest If til,
Adams men were not confident of having decided
majority IN New York; why should they wish


general ticket And if the Jacksonites were nc
aware of that fact, why shonld they exut at the re
lection of the proposed alteration The answer
are plain. The friends Of the Administration ha
rather have the whole vote of New York than


part--and the advocates of jackson had rather hay
a part than none II is true that such propositio
has been made and rejected, but it was made. u
believe, preinaturely-the present not being II
proper session. for that purpose. Legslatu,
pfaewly elected members will meet during the a
